title: 104_hr2083
content: The Act may be cited as the "Tax Reduction and Economic Growth Act of 1995" and includes provisions for tax reduction in the event of low growth. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must notify the President and Congress if economic growth is below 1.5% and national unemployment is above 6.5%. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must notify the President and Congress if economic growth is below 1.5% and national unemployment is above 6.5%. Testing periods are defined for notification purposes, including quarters before and after the notification. Presidential authorization is required for temporary tax reductions. After notification from the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, the President may declare temporary income tax reductions for a specific year to stimulate the economy. The declaration must be sent to Congress. If approved by Congress, temporary tax reductions will be effective for taxable years in the specified calendar year. The President may declare temporary income tax reductions for a specific year to stimulate the economy. The rates in the tax tables will be reduced by a specified percentage, and the tax amounts will be adjusted accordingly. The President can declare temporary income tax reductions to stimulate the economy, with withholding adjustments made to reflect the rate reduction. If economic growth requirements are met, a temporary surtax may be imposed. Effective for taxable years beginning in the first subsequent calendar year for which the economic growth requirements are satisfied, each tax rate in the tax tables of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will be increased by a certain percentage, except for the tax rate for individuals. The tax rates for individuals with Adjusted Gross Income under $50,000 and joint filers under $75,000 will not exceed the previous year's rates, and the tax amounts in the tables will be adjusted to reflect rate increases. The tax rates for individuals with Adjusted Gross Income under $50,000 and joint filers under $75,000 will not exceed the previous year's rates. The withholding tables will be adjusted to reflect rate increases for the subsequent calendar year. Economic growth requirements must be met before the beginning of each calendar year. The President determines economic growth and unemployment rates for tax rate adjustments. The percentage increase in tax is based on these determinations. The President estimates a percentage increase in tax rates under section 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to offset a decrease in receipts, without raising taxes for individuals with Adjusted Gross Income below certain thresholds. The President estimates a percentage increase in tax rates under section 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 to offset a decrease in receipts, without raising taxes for individuals with Adjusted Gross Income below certain thresholds. The percentage shall be published in the Federal Register before the beginning of the calendar year. SEC. 3. Treatment under pay-as-you-go procedures: Any changes in receipts from the Act will not affect the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985.
